Someone leaked half my RSA private key online, but insists my message "6225887024155981899333444095698229770958864707138638409939661412773527835964668506185823102434541056620005574000447841640595074459101200898328484507659415" is still safe. Prove them wrong and recover my secret!

The flag format is flag{...}
n=6551970287698795956599616535620296974685674996230275101305338323557840548280798521535177121946196784446958021531150446628116567641869896636770880019558489, e=3251872645668210862053822948782624454243201178975439762449306489118155477888551266290918241924213114338937330373870691175140174259320805632088653153483213, partial_p=10050460329164818957

---

## Challenge Technical Details
flag: flag{mpzcaf34}
cipher: RSA
ciphertext: 6225887024155981899333444095698229770958864707138638409939661412773527835964668506185823102434541056620005574000447841640595074459101200898328484507659415
vulnerability: partial key exposure
hint: A partial exposure of a prime number's bits can significantly weaken RSA security. Look into lattice-based techniques like Coppersmith's attack.
necessary_info: The flag format is flag{...}
n=6551970287698795956599616535620296974685674996230275101305338323557840548280798521535177121946196784446958021531150446628116567641869896636770880019558489, e=3251872645668210862053822948782624454243201178975439762449306489118155477888551266290918241924213114338937330373870691175140174259320805632088653153483213, partial_p=10050460329164818957
extra_info: p=63087761973635475859118926619198825092868259321656831826928141968840263026741, q=103854853663011215283651160316739964771010478366868587605785211173295413163029, Ï†(n)=6551970287698795956599616535620296974685674996230275101305338323557840548280631578919540475255054014360022082741286567890428042222437183283628744343368720
